That all the Clamour, Noise, and Raillery, which they had former∣ly raised against the Whiggs and Dis∣senters should cease, for a while; and to employ that useful Talent; without which the very being and nature o the Cause would sink and be forgotten in the World, the whole Stream, with all the Sluces and Flood-gates thereo should be turn'd down, open'd, and let fly at the New Ministry, and the Managers under them.

2. That upon all Occasions, the should endeavour to make their ju Complaints as popular as possible and principally on account of th Great Neglect of the promised Ze for the Church, which instead of givin her ease from Schisme and Factio is like to be fobb'd off with Buildi
a few Churches, and Repairing her Liturgy, things they could willingly have parted with, for but one Vote against Tolleration and Exemption.

3. That Anthony Marquis de Guiscard should in all their Writings and Dis∣courses be Damn'd for a Poultrone and a Scoundrel, not for Assassinating or Stabbing Mr. Harley, but for doing it by halves, and Stabbing him in the wrong place, since they have deter∣min'd in all their Assemblies and De∣bates, Nemine Contradicente, That he has been the only, or most material ob∣stacle to all the true measures of High Church, and the great Cause of all their Grievances aforesaid, and that he has their constant ill-will, Back-bles∣ings, and Anathema's accordingly.

4. That they should endeavour to ring as many of their Friends to this ew Society as is possible; who should e all Engag'd upon Parole of Honour pursue the just measures of the hole, in order to obtain a redress of the Grievances aforesaid.

5. That of these Friends and Assist∣ts, they should forthwith apply emselves with all their Interest, to , IF POSSIBLE, some of the mbers of the H ... of C ....
to their Society, and as many as they could of the Dignified Clergy; as to the Inferiour Clergy, one of the Soci∣ety stood up and acquainted them, that he was empower'd from Dr. Sa∣cheverell to assure them, That both he and all his Disciples of the Inferiour Priests and Deacons, were with them heart and hand, and he immediately produc'd his Commission from the Doctor for his Credentials.
6. Lastly, That some Honourable Name should be consider'd of for their Meeting, in order to perpetuate their Endeavours, and Record both it and their Persons to Posterity, in Perpetuam rei Memoriam.

It fell out unhappily, that while the Society were deliberating upon the Eternizing their Memory in History, and to that end giving themselves a Name; a Gentleman of Quality comes into the Tavern, and coming up to the Bar, enquires for the Assembly by the word OCTOBER; accordingly the Master of the House sends th Drawer up Stairs with the Gentleman to shew him the Room. The Drawer goes up to the first space in the Stairs when seeing another Drawer at th
top of the Stairs, he stopt; and calling up to the other Drawer, Will, says he, shew the Gentleman to the Club. What Club says Will? D—ye, the Fellow's a Fool, says the t'other, the October Club: So he carries him in.

In the very moment this happen'd, Sir Thomas—sends his Footman to the Tavern, to see if the Company was met; Jack, says Sir Thomas, Go to the Bell and enquire if the Gentlmen of the Club are come? If they don't understand you by that, give them the word, OCTOBER. Jack, a blundering West-country Booby comes up to the Bar decently enough, but asking once or twice, and the People being busy, and not minding him, he stood like a Mute a while; a Drawer by that time being a little at leisure, took notice of him, Who do you look for, says the Drawer? THE OCTOBER CLUBB, says the Innocent Clown, bawling it aloud. Up two pair of Stairs in the Great Room, says the Draw∣er, and up Stairs goes the Footman.

As the D—I would have it, who was certainly their G—d father, Three Gentlemen comes in at the very
moment to ask for October, and they hears the Boy enquire as before, and up Stairs they go with him.

Just as they were come in, the Society were in Debate as above for some Ho∣nourable Designation to bestow on themselves to Eternise the memory of their Assembly, when the first Gentle∣man stands up, and Addressing himself merrily to Esq; H—the Chairman for the time being; Mr. Chairman, says he, I think we may save our selves the trouble of this Debate, for if I mistake not our Society is Christned already, and so tells them his story of the two Drawers. While he is speaking, Sir William—being one of the three Gen∣tlemen abovesaid, stands up, says he, I felicitate you all upon your new Title of Honour, Gentlemen, and so tells his story of Sir Thomas's Footman.

Several in the Society took offence at it, and moved that the Master of the House might be spoken to, that care might be taken of it; but it was got among the Drawers, and from thence it went among the Footmen, and it was to no more purpose to go about to stop it then, than my Lord Haver∣sham's
Thumb to the Tide at Graves∣end.
Thus much for the Original of the Name.

We thought to have given you a brief Historical Account here of the diligent Endeavours of the Members of this Club, for so we are now to call them, to Grace their Assembly with the Attendance of some of our Na∣tions Representatives: But they ha∣ving met with a great Mortification on that Head, not being able, ac∣cording to their Desire and Expecta∣tions, to bring any of that Body to Joyn with them, no, not one; and the Design of this being only to speak to the Honour and Advantage of the Society, we are unwilling to leave up∣on Record any thing so much to their Disadvantage and Discouragement.

The History of the many bright Ornaments of the Church who came dayly over to them, and of the En∣crease of their Number from two Originals, recited to near One Hun∣red and Eighty MEMBERS; the constant Flux of Assistants from the either House of Con—ation, the farther proceedings of the Diligent Emissaries
they employ'd, and the like, these may afford a large Field of most use∣ful History, and which in time may be made more publick for the Informa∣tion of the Age, and the Caution of Posterity.

At present we shall only acquaint you, that in pursuance of the five Propositions mentioned above, the Gentlemen applied themselves with Great Diligence, and some say, with unexpected Success, to propagate the Cause they were Embark'd in, (viz.) to Erect a new Faction of Malecon∣tents among us, the Nation not be∣ing Divided enough before; and upon all occasions to go about Murmuring, Complaining, and raising Jealousies among the People, against the Queen and her new Administration:
For still omitting needful Security to the Church, which remains in th same Danger as before.
For Encouraging the Factious an Evil principled Dissenters.
For Declining the Advantages of a Hereditary Claim to the Crown.
For Carrying on the War with th same fury as formerly.

For setting up for a Moderate ma∣nagement of Affairs.
And the like.

It happen'd one day, in the prose∣cution of these Affairs, three Gentle∣men were Introduc'd to their Society, whose Faces were not well known; on a suddain a certain Damp spread upon the Countenances of the rest, and they began to look upon one another; the Business of the Society seem'd to stop, and the Gentlemen all in little Com∣mittees, of two, three, five, seven, and the like, talking upon private matters, till Sir M—standing up mov'd the Chairman to call to the order of the Society, which was done, and some∣body mentioning the bringing in of three Strangers, G—L—C—stood up and answer'd for them, That they were three Honest Gentlemen of North-Britain, and all of his acquaintance: upon which all were satisfied and fell to Business again.
However this occasion'd a New Debate, started by Sir H—M—, a worthy Member of the Society, of what sort of People they should Admit or Exclude from their Society.

The previous Question took up some time, and occasion'd several very Learned Speeches, (viz.) Whether they should Exclude any kind of Peo∣ple or no? But this was carried in the affirmative for many Reasons; especially this, That tho' their Grie∣vances were to be made as popular, and the Reasons of their Discon∣tents as publick as possible, yet the Measures they were to take for the bringing it to pass, and the Persons and Engines they might emyloy, as well as their own Persons, it would be necessary should be concealed as much as possible.

This being Resolv'd, the next thing to be Consider'd was, What sort of People were to be Admitted, or Ex∣cluded; in which their Debates were very remarkable on many Accounts and we shall give you an Abstract o some of them, tho' the Learned Speeches made on this occasion, by Sir P—, Sir H—, Sir M—and others, are, for want of room i this Tract, purposely omitted, thing otherwise worthy of Eternal Remark especially as coming from Men know never to have spoken Sence befor
and therefore certainly speaking by supernatural Inspiration now: A most sublime Testimony to the Goodness of their Cause, and a Token of the Great Success they expect to attend them.

The first proposal was about a Whigg; The Word was no sooner nam'd, but an universal Hiss begin∣ning among the Clergy at the upper end of the Room, spread it self throughout the whole Company: There was a Wiser Man than most among them, who Mov'd the Affir∣mative; he told them there were some High-flyers among the Whiggs, and as all Hot Principles was useful to their Designs, he thought it was a good piece of Policy to receive such, as Tools for their Work.

But it was answer'd those Tools might be made use of at second hand, and without doors, and so he was over-rul'd, and all manner of Whiggs, old Whiggs, or Modern Whiggs were Excluded, only with a reserve for my Lord—Haversham's Ghost, if he thought fit to appear, W—P—, and Mr. R—, my Lord ∵ R—
W—, and the D—of A—ll, three Scots Presbyterians, and two Quakers.

It was long indeed before those could be allow'd, but at last a Learn∣ed Distinction was accepted in their Favour, (viz.) That they were all Friends to the Pretender: So they were admitted as Jacobites, not as Whiggs, no Favour being allow'd to the latter upon any Terms what∣ever.

It was next Debated, whether Pa∣pists should be admitted into their Society, and it was carried for a per∣mission, after much Debate, with this Restriction: “”Provided, Nevertheless, and it is hereby Enacted by the Autho∣rity aforesaid, That no Papist be ad∣mitted into this Society who has abov 300 s. a year Estate in Land within this Kingdom. It may be matter Speculation why such an Exception a this should be made: But the Case very plain, for it was alledg'd, Th the Papists of greater Estates, th they were willing enough to hav the Revolution of this Nation u¦ravell'd, and the Royal Line, as the
call it, restor'd; yet they see so much improbability in the Success, and how they are so certain to be ruin'd in the attempt by these sort of Men, that generally speaking, they are en∣clin'd to sit still and be quiet, till they have some surer Game to play; and therefore least these Wiser-Papists should make some prudent, moderate steps, to the prejudice of the High∣flying hairbrain'd Principles, and so prevent their ruining themselves, which they are resolv'd upon in spight of Common Sense; for this reason they Excluded such, at the same time Admitting all the Guiscardins, French-Spies, Desperadoes and Mad-men, as well Papists as others.

We should here have descended to the affirmative of the Debate, and given you some Distinguishing Cha∣racters of the sorts they have agreed to admit, and the manner of their admission: But this, together with the Characters of the Persons, we are obliged, for want of room, to adjourn to the farther History of their Pro∣ceedings, which is preparing to be made publick; in which Account, their Principles, Politicks and Persons,
may have justice done them more at large.

Mean time we hope these Historical and Authentick Memoirs of their Ori∣ginal may be to the satisfaction of the Reader, and may be allow'd to have answer'd its Title, (viz.) The Secret History of the October Clubb.
We thought also to have given you a New Poem to the Honour and Glory of the Society, a true Original, by a Member of the Clubb: But we are oblig'd to reserve it for a farther op∣portunity.
